captions.text:
Demonstrators outside the Iranian Embassy
near Hyde Park Gate, in London, were a familiar

sight in the first few days of May, 1980.
The reason they were there underlined the

complexities of Middle Eastern politics at
the time.

Five Arab gunmen had taken over the building
and held the twenty people inside at the time

as hostages. May the 5th was the sixth day
of the siege and the gunmen were getting impatient.

They shot dead one of their hostages, the
Iranian Press Attaché, Abbas Lavasani, and

threatened to kill another every half hour
unless their demands - the release of ninety

one Arab prisoners in Iran - were met. The
time had come for the authorities to act.

The Special Air Service had been called in
to help the police, and for the next few minutes

took over the whole operation. Anyone watching
television that evening, hoping to see the

World Snooker Championships or a play, found
themselves witnessing a real life drama instead,

as the team prepared to blast their way into
the building.

Four of the five gunmen shot dead by the SAS.
One of the hostages, a BBC sound recordist,

Sim Harris, who six days earlier had gone
to the Embassy to collect a visa, was steered

back into a safe room. The Embassy had started
to burn as soon as the SAS had thrown in their

first explosives. By now it was well alight,
but everyone was out of the building. The

whole exercise had taken just eleven minutes.
The SAS men involved disappeared as secretly

as they'd arrived. It was an incident that
did much to enhance their reputation for ruthless

military efficiency. The hostages were taken
away for medical checks, after what turned

out to be the last of the Middle East's surrogate
wars fought out on the streets of Britain.

title: SAS Storm Iranian Embassy in London (1980)

On this day in - 1980 – Operation *Nimrod*: The British Special Air Service 
storms the Iranian embassy in London after a six-day siege.﻿

comments.author: Tony England

comments.text:
Pijef...

I am afraid your are wrong about the SAS not operating at sea as well as 
air and land...etc.. I have worked in my current profession with x members 
on both sides! The name SAS is a historical one, as they parachuted 
traditionally as their initial preferred method of entry in N Africa, then 
Malaya etc..to Pink Panther Landrovers proving a safer alternative as well 
as Yomping. The SAS do train with the SEALS as do, arguably the more elite 
SBS... and for the record, the SAS do have a water based unit... The SBS, 
 then SAS, wrote the modern special forces rule book... applied with huge 
successes in Africa, Northern France, Malaya, Borneo, Oman, Rhodesia, 
Sierra Leone; Gulf, Eastern Europe Afghan Ireland .......Successfully on 
all counts!

The SEALS and Green Beret (Green Beret being the first) were based on an 
American model conceived by his attachment to the SAS in Malaya, and he 
then set up the Green Beret... Unfortunately, The American did not follow 
the SAS rule book completely, and the training ethos suffered somewhat. 
Probably a cultural difference as a reason for that. Not to mention, 
fighting in Borneo, was a far harsher environment than Vietnam, where the 
brits and Anzac SP's operated successfully including along side the Koreans 
in South Nam, with very little loss of life or difficulties...

As for the water based work, the SBS are UK's specialist amphibious unit, 
existing (even if by a different name at the time) before the SAS in the 
Second World War (cockleshell heroes). This was one of reasons why the UK 
suffered less casualties than the Americans during D Day.  The SBS 
specialised in beach rec cons before sending regular soldiers to 
unchartered territory to be butchered....

Paddy Ashdown pioneered many of the submarine entry diving techniques as 
well as mastering the protection of oil rigs in the North Sea... A very 
harsh and dangerous logistically issue in itself! While the SAS and Boat 
Service have now joined in training selection, Maggie was always very fond 
of the Boat Service and left many more clandestine missions to them... She 
preferred the 'Not by Strength, but By Guile' approach to business, even 
though she was very fond of the more published SAS. Considering the Boat 
Service come from the toughest and longest standard entry unit in Nato 
(Royal Marines), to then, if successful, be selected for the gruelling 
Mountain Troop, then higher to the SBS! This means the bench mark is 
already higher than the SAS who traditionally, unlike the Marines, 
recruited from the Guards and Paras, RAF regiment and Marines who failed 
SBS selection!...

Lastly, you can not ever forget the importance of experience...especially 
accompanied with a record of successes that have far outweighed the 
failures... Even Storman Norman wound his cynical neck in, when he then 
realised the value of the SAS /BS; eyes on the ground skill and MI6 
surveillance methods.

Rant over ;-)﻿

comments.author: P1mpMyBr1de

comments.text:
+P1mpMyBr1de ... The media jumped on the hype, probably due to the Bravo 2 
0 book, which Mc Nab spoke quite a few porkies... just to sell the story... 
Chris Ryan was not too impressed by this... If you want to read a story 
about just how good these guys are, read the Battle of Mirbat and the 
campaign in Malaya and Borneo... They earned their reputation way before 
the media even new of their existence! Oh, and of course the North African 
campaign, Sierra Leone.... If you prefer a little more modesty and 
mystique, read about the SBS... First Into Action... a far better read then 
McNab... The Boat Service were Maggie's preference, due to their more 
secretive and thoughtful approach relative to the SAS... this was proved 
during the Black opps, when the both joined forces with the Yanks after the 
Iraq war...

comments.text:

comments.author: Ade B

comments.text:
+P1mpMyBr1de I think Rudy's comment answer your point.. It reminds me of 
the IRA and something Thatcher once said.. (when considering that the 
British Army was considerably larger than that of the terrorists'..) she 
said the British Army have to be effective 100 percent of the time (to 
prevent mass violent acts) ; where as the IRA only have to be effective 
once to cause chaos! 


As for contesting the SAS are the world's best... they simply are, and have 
the most experience in hostage rescue..and special forces applications! Sir 
Peter DeBilliere ( UK's most decorated soldier) established the world's 
first anti terrorist/close quarter specialist unit in the SAS and have 
taught nations willing to listen.. (The SAS/BS have often been privately 
involved in other famous Foreign siege's without taking the credit) 


Those taught have included the Americans, Germans, Anzacs and many more 
nations... And unlike the others, it's members have to have been in the 
Army/Marines etc for at least 3 years, plus experience SAS operators too... 
This standard also applies to the perhaps the most elite unit of them all, 
the SBS. They have taught the world how to rescue hostages from boats and 
and climb oil rigs located in the treacherous and cold North Sea, without 
the aid of boats.. just Subs! Delta force does not require experienced 
soldiers to become members. They set up their unit, based on our model. 
Here endeth the very brief lesson.. :-)
comments.author: Ade B

comments.text: None of the SAS died
comments.author: Titan -X40 - A British Gamer!

comments.text:
+P1mpMyBr1de Hostage situations are notoriously hard to pull off without 
casualties, if anything goes wrong, they can get real messy for everyone. 
You can only fit so many men in a room, so the numbers don't really matter 
initially, anyway those breaching teams did their jobs well, and if they 
fell, the others behind them would've picked up the slack. Remember, the 
enemy was on the defensive in a prepared position and did not have to worry 
about accidentally shooting hostages, it was a tough situation. No matter 
how you cut it, those men did a fantastic job that day.

comments.author: Mr.English

comments.text:
0:35 looks like a dummy on that stretcher?  Two BBC guys were present that 
day, hmmm?  One BBC guy was released after a day or two complaining of a 
tummy ache?  So why didn't the rest of the hostages complain of a belly 
ache, so they would have all been freed too?  Why did that guy (the one who 
was shot) and was seen looking like a dummy on a stretcher, get the right 
steaming hump when one of the patsies scrawled a bit of graffiti on the 
wall?  Was it his house?  No, but he was there as a hostage held against 
his will for 5 days without complaining.  However, the mainstream media 
would have me to believe that a simple bit of graffiti got his wild up and 
he demanded to be shot because he was so angry about a bit of graffiti but 
had no problem being held captive!?!?  I've got a sas book called ''This is 
the sas'' by Tony Geraghty.  It says about the siege ''It was May 1980 
before the SAS was called upon to perform publicly the techniques it had 
rehearsed in secret for seven years"  Sounds like to me it was all a false 
flag event.  The unsuspecting actors playing the bad guys were murderd by 
the sas, except for one who was rescued by the other highly paid crisis 
actor hostges who thought it was going too far killing the fake baddies. 
 He got a 25 year jail term, even though no other convict had ever seen him 
in any jail?  Robin Horsfall who took part said 25 years was too long. 
 Interesting thing to say Robin?  Perhaps he knew it was all a hoax.  The 
death and subsequent humiliation of John McAleese doesn't sit well with me 
either.  Was he about to blow the lid on what really happened that day? 
 Nah the whole thing was an ultimate farce.﻿

comments.author: Tony England

comments.text:
+pijef I do not follow your point, except that you may think the SBS are a 
separate team... In one respect they are. They have their own Regiment, 
(Royal Marines) motto; history and cultures and the fact that until 
recently, both enjoyed independent selection processes.. This has all 
changed. Now army can attempt the SBS selection, without being in the Royal 
Marines for 3 years first (The SBS originally being only open to Marines, 
set a higher starting bench mark then any regular entry unit in the world, 
as the RM's have the longest training regime in NATO ... Now both units 
share the same selection process, then go off and do there special 
duties..This was due to government cuts.. They operate as part of joint 
team, with 2 other sections - Special Reconnaissance Regiment (SRR), and 
Special Forces Support Group (SFSG)., the SAS being the other part.  


Secondly, the 22 SAS Sabre specialise and focus in specific aspects of war, 
unlike 21 and 23 SAS who have other functions...


22 nd SAS specialities 
1. Air Troop
2.BOAT Troop
3. Mobility Troop
4 Mountain Troop
All members will usually tour all the devisions...
1


As I mentioned before, the SAS have a specialist water based squadron... 
Independent in principle like the anti terrorist unit, a separate squadron, 
in this example with close quarter specialities etc...

comments.text:
+pijef I am afraid your are wrong about the SAS not operating at sea as 
well as air and land...etc.. I have worked in my current profession with x 
members on both sides! The name SAS is a historical one, as they parachuted 
traditionally as their initial preferred method of entry in N Africa, then 
Malaya etc..to Pink Panther Landrovers proving a safer alternative as well 
as Yomping. The SAS do train with the SEALS as do, arguably the more elite 
SBS... and for the record, the SAS do have a water based unit... The SBS, 
 then SAS, wrote the modern special forces rule book... applied with huge 
successes in Africa, Northern France, Malaya, Borneo, Oman, Rhodesia, 
Sierra Leone; Gulf, Eastern Europe Afghan Ireland .......Successfully on 
all counts!

The SEALS and Green Beret (Green Beret being the first) were based on an 
American model conceived by his attachment to the SAS in Malaya, and he 
then set up the Green Beret... Unfortunately, The American did not follow 
the SAS rule book completely, and the training ethos suffered somewhat. 
Probably a cultural difference as a reason for that. Not to mention, 
fighting in Borneo, was a far harsher environment than Vietnam, where the 
brits and Anzac SP's operated successfully including along side the Koreans 
in South Nam, with very little loss of life or difficulties...

As for the water based work, the SBS are UK's specialist amphibious unit, 
existing (even if by a different name at the time) before the SAS in the 
Second World War (cockleshell heroes). This was one of reasons why the UK 
suffered less casualties than the Americans during D Day.  The SBS 
specialised in beach rec cons before sending regular soldiers to 
unchartered territory to be butchered....

Paddy Ashdown pioneered many of the submarine entry diving techniques as 
well as mastering the protection of oil rigs in the North Sea... A very 
harsh and dangerous logistically issue in itself! While the SAS and Boat 
Service have now joined in training selection, Maggie was always very fond 
of the Boat Service and left many more clandestine missions to them... She 
preferred the 'Not by Strength, but By Guile' approach to business, even 
though she was very fond of the more published SAS. Considering the Boat 
Service come from the toughest and longest standard entry unit in Nato 
(Royal Marines), to then, if successful, be selected for the gruelling 
Mountain Troop, then higher to the SBS! This means the bench mark is 
already higher than the SAS who traditionally, unlike the Marines, 
recruited from the Guards and Paras, RAF regiment and Marines who failed 
SBS selection!...

Lastly, you can not ever forget the importance of experience...especially 
accompanied with a record of successes that have far outweighed the 
failures... Even Storman Norman wound his cynical neck in, when he then 
realised the value of the SAS /BS; eyes on the ground skill and MI6 
surveillance methods.

comments.author: ikram miah

comments.text:
+Olav Bergman Holding hostages for religious purpose would have lead to no 
demands, it could have been a message, "Bow before Allah" ect ect. These 
guys had clear demands and wanted political prisoners released.

There was no mention of dying for a god, no forced religious worship, the 
men did not even cover the women's head with a burka (as any extremist 
would have) There was no forced religious conversion, no discrimination 
based on religious belief.

This was not religious moron. Saying it was is only proving what a retard 
you are. The government in iran may practice Islamic law, but that is like 
say we in the UK are NOT religious because we do not force worship in 
church every Sunday. It is moronic.

Game. Set. Match.

comments.text:
I have complete respect John McAleese and what they did I think a lot of 
people dod't actual get what i mean with this comment.

Trying to do this with the team they had and the back up they had is an 
impossibility now covering all the angles of media public media.

A total rethink of the support and the such. it support, media blackout, 
shutting down the local telephone, wireless networks, mobile networks, 
broadband connections the list goes on.

Though I know rf jammers do block the carrier radio wave of mobiles this is 
not true for wifi or hardwire. ( wifi is another jammer think it is a m20 
of thing)

Where as I have full respect for the sas ( eg the famous lofty) the whole 
tecnques and support to do anything like this now has had to be and has 
been re-thought.
